Now the Trump White House is on the Statue of Liberty
The safest sign of regime change is when they start attacking the statues .
Americans like any other – hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein at Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , certainly knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe in a heated dispute with Jim Acosta of CNN about the president ’ s proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration with the Statue of Liberty .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A horde of boat owners and liberty imitators would have lynched him if he had done so .

But he attacked their importance , and in particular the importance that was attributed to her when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument , to his base .
When Miller Acosta claimed : " I do not want to go into a whole thing about history , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that the world enlightens .
The poem to which you refer , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty . '
Miller is quite right , but , as he himself said , it is not really about history .

It is about the contemporary resonance of the uprising words of Lazarus , the only country in which a state invites not only any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your mothers , your poor , / your afflicted masses , who seek to breathe freely / the wretched waste of your rich coasts ' .
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' was better visible on our screens .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people were not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict over the importance of a statue is part of a broader political and cultural dispute : it is indeed a conflict over the importance of America .
Lazarus - and their friends who worked to place their words on the ground after their death - knew very well that they were doing a highly political act .
The sculpture was supposed to show the links between French and American Republicanism by representing , in a depressed classical picture , the female embodiment of freedom .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem the female figure is no longer abstract - she received one voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of the exiles .
The poem ’ s combination with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people from the right wing wanted to change it long ago .

The great shreihal Rush Limbaugh , a kind of Johannes of the buyer for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty is not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative , bringing the American flame into the surrounding world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It is intended to carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch is not intended to clarify the way to the United States . '
Though quite unusual , Limbaugh has found something here .
The importance of the statue is in fact a question of the point of view of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see them as seen by exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible trips on the decks of ships .
It is , in the truest sense , about seeing the world from the perspective of people , seeking refuge , and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome they must hear .
And that , of course , is not the prospect that Miller and Trump ever want to recognize .
Their torch is not intended to illuminate the path , but to inflame hatred , which is its only source of power .

When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It even rarely uses a pot .

In their wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai Regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .

Of course it can be dangerous to work late : most villagers are unemployed and many drink hard , and there are the soldiers here .
No one dares to walk around in the village after 17 o 'clock ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the Papua Highlands , a former Dutch colony that was inaugurated in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders had to vote in front of the occupying forces by a public rally .

An existing movement that stirred up independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which maintains control of the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part Papua New Guinea encompassing the eastern part of the island .
The trip includes a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire and a morning 5-hour car ride with the rental car .

We were not accustomed to wearing this clothing ,  Degei says and points out their lively , hand-woven turban , their dark shirt and their bright skirt .

Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and some of the worst rates of child mortality and literacy in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s Goldland .

The largest and most profitable Goldmine in the world , Grasberg , owned by Freeport McMoran from Phoenix , is located just 60 miles from Paniai , a high land province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport , worth $ 3.1 billion , cut gold and copper .

But these wealth is a source of misery for the Papua , ensuring that Indonesia ’ s powerful military retains a suffocating presence .
